author: Becky Bach

comments.message: The CDC has a great website with an abundance of information http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/ and resources for people wanting to start a marketing campaign http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/resources/index.html, but I notice there isn't a number to call if a person thinks he/she has Ebola.

Hey Becky, this post by another member of the community might be interesting to you https://openideo.com/challenge/fighting-ebola/ideas/the-ebola-toll-free-sms-helpline as well as this one https://openideo.com/challenge/fighting-ebola/ideas/rapidpro-unicef-a-simple-app-to-enhance-communication. How might these systems differ in the US and in West Africa? How can we leverage local contexts and cultures to support the same activity?

Hi Becky, have you got an image you could update your post with to help tell your story in more detail? Perhaps something representing a phone and a community connected to it. If you need inspiration check out http://ideo.pn/vis-uals.

I agree -- I think sms would work better in Africa for education, prevention and a centralized number here for patients to call so the CDC could network with local hospitals to pick up the potential patient and take them to a prepared hospital.

description: Launch marketing campaign, staff phone line with trained volunteers, coordinate with state and local leaders.
summary: I believe the US should have a single phone number, perhaps operated by the CDC, that anyone who suspects they have Ebola or similar symptoms should call so hospitals, ambulance, etc. can prepare.
title: Central phone number for US
